It's a good game it just has too much garbage to filter through. If you're experienced at these games you're also going to have to gimp yourself a lot to find any enjoyment out of it otherwise its going to be too easy. The modifier stacking in this game is insane, its practically Nioh levels of insanity where you can basically bypass the combat system with diablo power stacking through buffs, rings, consumables ect. The ashes of war are also far too powerful and are easily spammed without consequence. Most of your power is defined by them where neutral play matters far less.Most of the open world is forgettable and redundant only there to pad the game time and appeal to a different audience that enjoys that kind of experience. Liurnia of the Lakes is by far the worse example of this and its always a slog to go through even when you're skipping through 90% of it. The underground areas are also vapid derivative empty spaces of time wasting. The worst is Nokstella, a complete waste of time that you cant even use the horse to trudge through. Most of these areas only serve to plod along the plot of the most self indulgent unlikeable character in the game. It's all extremely disappointing.The pacing also suffers as well. Most of the game feels too samey in terms of enemy power level where the player starts to outscale them until you get to mountaintops of the giants and then the enemy power curve leaps exponentially. Caelid, Luiurina, Altus, Leyndell Capital all feel very similar in terms of enemy power. The bridge between them and Mountaintops is supposed to be Volcano Manor/Mt Gelmir but even that feels way undertuned compared to mountaintops. My issue with this is that it really feels like the game doesn't start until you get to mountaintops as the stuff you did beforehand feels irrelevant. Playing through NG+ cycles only makes the gap wider and its a real problem I have with this game.With all that being said this game is still worth it despite all of these problems. The boss design is solid and the movement options like crouching and jumping feel good and don't overly oppress the core dark souls combat. Legacy dungeons are by far the best this game offers, areas like Stormveil Castle, Farum Azula, Miquella's Haligtree, Leyndell Capital are very well designed and are worth trudging through the open world to get to.The core combat is still dark souls and the formula is very addicting where you can spend hours of fulfillment killing hordes of enemies. Although the game does prod you into abusing cheesy mechanics or diablo power stacking, you never have to and there is a level of satisfaction gained after achieving a certain level of mastery over the challenges the game puts you through. I think this is what keeps me hooked to this game above all else.

Fun game and fantastic world. Exploration is definitely rewarded.Difficulty is on the high side but not horribly unfair.For those who don't want the challenge but would like to try the game mods are just a google search away and there are some that lower the difficulty or nearly eliminate it if you just want closer to tourist mode. If you go this route I do recommend trying the game later on with mods off once you have some experience with the mechanics.While some starting classes are more powerful out the gate than others I recommend going with whichever catches your fancy or fits what you believe to be your style. All starting classes ultimately become whatever you make them through gear and leveling.With the DLC around the corner it is a good time to get started. Though waiting for a deal once the DLC hits is also an option.Overall definitely recommend for any gamer who likes swords, sorcery, and exploration.

Elden Ring? Oh, please. That so-called "challenge" was child's play for someone of my caliber. Every achievement in that game was practically handed to me on a silver platter. From conquering bosses with my eyes closed to navigating the open world with one hand tied behind my back, it was all too easy. I finished the game before most players even figured out how to swing a sword properly. Maybe next time they'll make a game worthy of my skills, but until then, I'll bask in the glory of effortlessly conquering Elden Ring.

Jaw-dropping experience.Not the best combat out there, you will die, and i mean, a lot. Elden Ring is so rewarding, so fulfilling.You will have to go back and forth multiple times, because you are probably under-level, but that's why this game is so unique and special. I never thought i would like souls-like games, but exploring this open-world is something i have never seen in any other videogame ever before. it is truly remarkable.Every location you explore is incredibly built and designed, with tons of secrets, hidden places and doors, multiple precious items, and incredible views to see.I truly think everyone should play this game, atleast once, in his life, it is simply incredible, something taken from fantasy books.Just have in mind that you're most of the times, the victim. You will have to farm EXP, kill a lot of mobs, get good gear and upgrade it, until you get stronger, in order to go into new areas of the map, search a lot online, you will probably need it, as zones have level caps, but this game wont tell you anything, literally, anything, but well... i guess that's the beauty of it.Be patient, do not rush enemies, study their moves and patterns first, then take your move and kill them, dodge or parry exactly in the last second, remember, this is Elden Ring, exploration is key, if you cant beat an enemy, do not worry, come back later.For 3 times i thought to myself, i m not ever playing this again, but i was wrong.TRY. It's fantastic. Even for people unfamiliar with FromSoft's other games, this game is accessible in spite of its lineage of difficulty. There are multiple things you can do to gain strength, and also multiple strategies you can employ within combat itself.The addition of the open world and crafting system is a huge boon to the formula. The open world encourages exploration, which has always been a strong point in FromSoft games, and also opens up tons of opportunities to power up through side activities and explore quests through the various characters you can find and talk to. The crafting system also functions as a way to ease exploration by creating useful tools, as well as make combat more manageable through crafting throwables, ammo, status inflicting items and buffs.The moment to moment gameplay is vastly improved as well. You still have your light and heavy attacks, your guarding and parrying, and your magical spells in two different flavors. But all of these features have improved in a number of ways, including new ways to interact in combat. Combat Arts can be a fundamental part of the way you play, opening up lots of new moves and abilities, the new guard counter allows for a much more defensive playstyle to punish opponents after they attack, and heavy (especially charged heavy) attacks can break your opponents stance to open them up to critical hits. If you're struggling with a fight, changing your strategy can be a viable option, and if that fails then opening up the crafting menu can also give you the edge you need. If all else fails, you can rely on your fellow Tarnished and summon a friend (or stranger) to help you out in multiplayer.This game is the best version released of FromSoft's formula that they've been refining for years. As someone who's played every game in the Souls series, including Bloodborne and Sekiro, this one is my favorite. And here's to hoping the DLC improves on this already great game even more!

For me it was a grind to just get through it.I guess I have gotten older and want to play whats fun not whats trendy, it just wasnt for me. I am not a combat efficientato by any means and the options, spells, ashes of war, summons were all good systems. At its core though, for ME, its just tiresome. Why or how can poison go through a wall? Why can a bad guy plunge his axe through rock and hit you on the other side? Why do bosses have unlimited stamina? Elden Ring had some of the most aggressive boss battles I have ever played through in a From Software game. Hands down. The last section of the game is littered with them back to back to back, its insane. Granted the open world gives opportunities to gain some flasks back but thats so you dont have to go back to a spot to heal again, it didnt make it more accepting in terms of difficulty. The dungeons generally are filled with the same wolves, pots, and gremlins, with a few traps and a boss or two at the end of it. Once you get the goodies in the dungeon or cave you usually find yourself dead at the bosses door or near death with no flasks forcing you to death with the boss so that you can just run all the way to the door again if there was no stake to bring you back to near the door. Fighting on the horse was fun although, the farther you get into the game, the more you realize the horse is just another piece of armor that most enemies are going to be able to kill. Its fast but they are faster.I think for people who love this genre and the Souls franchise this is a dream come true. Its a big expansive world with enough variety for people who want to see it, and lots of things to explore. More mini bosses, more dungeons, more exploration, more armor/weapons, summons, just more more more. But its also just more frustration, cheap boss battles and the ever present git gud mantra of some really just becomes icing on the cake, yeah, I dont need to do this anymore.

I love how creative you can get with all the different kinds of builds, makes for tons of replayability. Don't be afraid to run passed enemies or come back to fight a boss later. You'll likely need a guide for NPC storylines though, no shame in that. Music is peak.

All weapons feel fun and unique to handle and the variety of builds you can play with is amazing, and when you gain access to respecing, the opportunities for changing your strategies with bosses is second to none.I truly could keep talking about this game, its impact on me as a person and truly just how fun it is to pick up and play. But I'll leave that for another platform. But take it from me, as I've spent 190 hours finding as many facets of this game as possible, please at least give it a go. It's so wonderful and I think anyone can find the enjoyment in it.Also the DLC is right around the corner so no better time to play this game and prepare to take on the challenges in the Shadow of the Erdtree!

Elden Ring has the worst combat system out of all of Myazaki's games. Most of the bosses are impossible to kill if you are by yourself or are not over-leveled for that encounter. The golden knights are impossible to fight on your own, especially the draconic variants, the main bosses are almost all horrible and frustrating to fight against unless you are some kind of demi-god or have memorized all the moves they do. The bosses have inhuman reactions, constantly spam 15 move combos, and spam a variety of distance attacks if you stay away from them. If you try to fight a draconic golden knight by yourself, you will be there for weeks if you want to do it all on your own with no summons and also without grinding and finding moonveil katanas. It would have been great if the combat was like Sekiro but better and the bosses were not so insane. It doesn't feel like a fight, it feels like you when you were a kid and you were defending yourself against daddy with the belt. Having to dodge 99% of the attacks and wait for a small opening to hit once and run away is not fun or intense, I learned nothing. Its just one big slog, one big mess where you push through everything in the most tiring and nerve-wracking way possible, in the end you have to resort to summoning bots in the fight. But you quickly find out the bots suck, so you go even further, just summoning other players to fight for you as you stay away mostly and hope that you are not the only one left in the end. And if you are, then you have very little chance because the end phases of the bosses will destroy you without you even getting near them, whether it is in the form of a fireball ·õãhitspam, or lighting strikes which you cant even dodge because they track your character's rolls. If you didn't have Estus to chuck every five seconds, you would be ·ö†ucked, in that case might as well summon a whole army of players, just make the game an open MMO.By the way, most fights in this game are useless because the enemies just respawn after you kill them, whats the point of fighting them if not for drops or runes or whatever. You never have the satisfaction of clearing out an area of enemies, you just have to run past them over and over. The open world is empty, vast majority of items you pick up will be some sort of materials or some useless junk, you kill a massive knight in armor and you pick up a ·ö†ucking crusty mushroom off his body... You go off exploring an area you think contains something cool, only to find its empty or has a corpse/chest which has a "sliver of meat" on it. At the early game you are basically depressed because you can't find sensible equipment to use, you are forced to open the wiki online to manually look up where the hell the damn armor is located. Same thing with the quests, you have no idea which character goes where and what the quests are, you can even miss quests just by playing the game, so you have to look at the wiki. Not only is the armor hard to find, most of it is hideous, the designes are just fantasy garbage, more than half of it doesn't even make sense nor does it look good. Only a handful of the plate armors look somewhat historically inspired, the banished knight's armor looks the coolest but still has issues like the horn on the shoulder and the fuzzy hair on the back.I give this a 5/10

I'm going to be honest I have enjoyed fromsoft's games since the release of dark souls, I remember being a young kid hyped up and ready for a grueling sadomasochistic enjoyment of a never onslaught of death.With Elden Ring I've been disappointed.. the Bossfights and gameplay of half the game are copy pasted repeats of the content you first encounter in the game. With the speed and pace of boss battles being a frenzy of 5-7 hit combos, frequent unnatural delays meant to trip up a player, combine this with the half second input lag that frequently occurs on rolls, it's a recipe for disaster.This game took away from the experience of intuition that most souls games forced you to adapt yourself to, and instead require rote memorization of a boss' 20-30 possible moves and attacks to carefully dodge often requiring you to die a multitude times more than predecessors of the genre.Fights and combat are either overly difficult and needlessly long due to the abundance of flying and hyper-mobile enemies the size of 4 school busses, often needing to wait a full minute before you can get a single hit in. Or in the case of the elden beast, the final boss of the game running 10 football fields away requiring you to make a beeline 10-20 good times becoming an exhausting boring marathon of wacking a pinata with a stick on a treadmill. The late-game was a slew of lazy boss design and attack motions such as in the case of godfrey spamming a ground pound with the same animation 100 times in a row.The dungeons of the game are a boring slog, copy pasted over and over again with the same layout and bricks that put Skyrim to shame, filled with the same enemies you've fought the past half dozen times.While this is a good game, it's not the 10/10 GOTY everyone calls it, I'd dare anyone to venture beyond using mimic tear, spells, and rivers of blood to attempt a fight with a shortsword or club. Melee feels like crippling your knees with a bat before a 5k, whereas ranged builds are given an immense advantage that had not existed in prior iterations of the souls series.In essence I feel Fromsoft balanced their game around a multiplayer and coop experience which is even harder to find due to the endless amounts of cheats and mods, throughout the last 70 hours of playing I was never able to invade, find an invader, or even play a single match in the coliseum. Which makes me suspicious regarding the supposedly high player counts boasted of on steam.The art style is excellent, the lore and various questlines are intriguing, but the gameplay of the game bounces back and forth from being either far too easy, or punishing the player for using anything slower than a katana in melee combat, and at times making it NIGH impossible to score hits on certain enemies such as the fallingstar beast.I've never once wanted to speedrun a Dark Souls game, and with Elden Ring it couldn't be finished fast enough.

I'm going to be honest I have enjoyed fromsoft's games since the release of dark souls, I remember being a young kid hyped up and ready for a grueling sadomasochistic enjoyment of a never onslaught of death.With Elden Ring I've been disappointed.. the Bossfights and gameplay of half the game are copy pasted repeats of the content you first encounter in the game. With the speed and pace of boss battles being a frenzy of 5-7 hit combos, frequent unnatural delays meant to trip up a player, combine this with the half second input lag that frequently occurs on rolls, it's a recipe for disaster.This game took away from the experience of intuition that most souls games forced you to adapt yourself to, and instead require rote memorization of a boss' 20-30 possible moves and attacks to carefully dodge often requiring you to die a multitude times more than predecessors of the genre.Fights and combat are either overly difficult and needlessly long due to the abundance of flying and hyper-mobile enemies the size of 4 school busses, often needing to wait a full minute before you can get a single hit in. Or in the case of the elden beast, the final boss of the game running 10 football fields away requiring you to make a beeline 10-20 good times becoming an exhausting boring marathon of wacking a pinata with a stick on a treadmill. The late-game was a slew of lazy boss design and attack motions such as in the case of godfrey spamming a ground pound with the same animation 100 times in a row.The dungeons of the game are a boring slog, copy pasted over and over again with the same layout and bricks that put Skyrim to shame, filled with the same enemies you've fought the past half dozen times.While this is a good game, it's not the 10/10 GOTY everyone calls it, I'd dare anyone to venture beyond using mimic tear, spells, and rivers of blood to attempt a fight with a shortsword or club. Melee feels like crippling your knees with a bat before a 5k, whereas ranged builds are given an immense advantage that had not existed in prior iterations of the souls series.In essence I feel Fromsoft balanced their game around a multiplayer and coop experience which is even harder to find due to the endless amounts of cheats and mods, throughout the last 70 hours of playing I was never able to invade, find an invader, or even play a single match in the coliseum. Which makes me suspicious regarding the supposedly high player counts boasted of on steam.The art style is excellent, the lore and various questlines are intriguing, but the gameplay of the game bounces back and forth from being either far too easy, or punishing the player for using anything slower than a katana in melee combat, and at times making it NIGH impossible to score hits on certain enemies such as the fallingstar beast.I've never once wanted to speedrun a Dark Souls game, and with Elden Ring it couldn't be finished fast enough.
